title: Spatial Audio Processing with Large Language Model on Wearable Devices
author: Ayushi Mishra (University of Maryland), Yang Bai (University of Maryland), Priyadarshan Narayanasamy (University of Maryland), Nakul Garg (University of Maryland), Nirupam Roy (University of Maryland), ...
relevance_why: The integration of spatial audio context into Large Language Models (LLMs) aligns well with current trends in enhancing audio-based applications in AI, which is highly relevant to Dr. Liu's focus on audio and speech processing.
background: This paper addresses how to improve the understanding of spatial audio in wearable devices, allowing them to transcribe speech and locate sound sources directionally.
contribution: This paper introduces a novel framework that integrates spatial audio cues with Large Language Models, facilitating advanced spatial speech understanding for wearable applications.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods for spatial understanding typically involve large microphone arrays, which are impractical for wearable devices and often yield poor accuracy.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work employs a microstructure-based spatial sensing setup with a single microphone to achieve precise direction of arrival (DoA) estimation while minimizing hardware complexity.

key_innovation: Utilizes a compact microstructure to enable spatial audio processing from a monaural microphone, achieving high accuracy without extensive hardware.
real_world_impact: The findings could significantly enhance user experience in augmented reality and accessibility applications, leading to more intuitive interactions with technology.
limitations: The paper mentions future work directions such as elevating angle estimation and enhancing robustness across diverse real-world environments but does not specify current limitations in detail.

new_terms.Direction of Arrival (DoA): **Direction of Arrival (DoA)** refers to the angle at which a sound arrives at a microphone, which is crucial for spatial audio processing.
